revised_title: Effects of Axotomy on Adrenaline Content in Sympathetic Nerve Fibers
tldr: The study examines the changes in adrenaline content of sympathetic nerve fibers in the frog's heart after sectioning the vagosympathetic trunks. The results show an immediate increase in adrenaline content, followed by a loss of fluorescence and disintegration of the fibers. The findings suggest that the continued synthesis of adrenaline in the peripheral parts of the neurons, separated from their cell bodies, reveals a normal 'depletion' of nerve terminals due to a possible failure of the re-uptake mechanism for released adrenaline.
